caption_original: Sirmilik National Park was named after the Inuktitut word for 'the place of glaciers.' It is located in the northern geographic area of Baffin Island, Nunavut. You can enjoy one of the most ecologically diverse areas in the Arctic, which also happens to be home to the largest snow geese colony in the world! http://ow.ly/H75D30hfTxF #IndigenousLanguages Parks Canada

caption_original: The dancing bear is one of the most well-known subjects in Inuit art â”€ and the most challenging to carve. The entire stone has to be balanced on one leg without tipping over, but still look graceful as if it is in movement. One of the most renowned carvers of dancing bears is Nuna Parr. Check out some of his work: http://ow.ly/cA6L30hfVgH

caption_original: Caribou can be found in some of Canadaâ€™s coldest climates. They use their long legs and half-moon-shaped hooves to navigate deep snow across the Arctic tundra and boreal forests. caption_original: Beluga whales live in the Gulf of St. Lawrence (Quebec) and the Arctic waters of Canada, Greenland and Russia. caption_original: The Government of Canada is working with Teslin, Yukon, residents through the Northern REACHE program to install a biomass heating system and reduce reliance on fossil fuels.
